I honestly think this game is horrible. The mix of the app and the tabletop simply does not work well and should be one or the other but not both. Why do you even need a tabletop setup when everything could be done far more efficiently within an app? The components are numerous and almost of all of them are fiddly and time consuming, particularly the tiles. The small damage and equipment cards are practically illegible with very small print and grey writing over a grey background. The amount of randomness regarding dice rolling actions is ridiculous, frustrating, and unrealistic. For example, doing an attack action when firing a gun could require you to use any one of your character stats...really? Why would I make an influence roll to shoot a gun? The way the actions are rolled out make the character stats arbitrary. My last gripe is that the game is an over-textual railroad where players don't have much actual decision making and it takes forever to get through it. The next time this one comes up I think I will pass, sorry folks.

First of all I am not against apps in board games. I loved the way Alchemists used the app, and looking forward on how
First Martians: Adventures on the Red Planet and Rising 5 will use it.

However, the problem with MoM's design, is that there is no real need for a physical component. The app could have handled the character movement, the rolls, the conditions.

It feels odd and fiddly to select the monster that I want to attack on the app, choose how I attack it on the app, roll the physical dice, and input the result on the app? Why? Physically rolling the dice, and physically moving the plastic dolls around the map dose nothing for the gameplay, on the contrary it just creates disconnection, as you keep switching context.

Anyway, if you are running a Cthulhu RPG, than yes, the package is worth the money: you get some nice tiles and some nice plastic dolls, and as a bonus you get a decent board game, however if you are a board gamer, why on earth would you spend 100$ on a glorified app?

In the end there are some things that video games(and maybe rpgs) will always do better(theme, immersion), while board are better when it comes to creating interesting situations with tough choices. I think designers should understand that, and play to the boardgame's strength, rather than trying to do everything.

I did not enjoy playing Mansions of Madness so I'm going to start off with what I did like. I like the mansion rooms discovery mechanic. I liked the art. The miniatures are fine, though I very much dislike how sloppy the box is. There are plenty of minis and they are just thrown into a ziplock bag. From a roleplay perspective, I find having stats for each character is cool as, in practice, this would mean different characters would be better suited for different scenarios; however, stat checks are driven through sheer luck through dice rolls so the majority of the time if you have a bad roll, having 5 lore can be as useful as having 3 or less.

Now, as you can see, I can't even finish talking about the good parts without having something negative to say too. Mansions of Madness is driven through an application you play on a tablet or similar device. This wouldn't be a problem if the gameplay wasn't a luck driven slog with little puzzles that have absolutely NOTHING to do with Lovecrafts Mythos. The descriptions of events and monster encounters are written the same way, all the time. The Mythos phase is terrible and completely disconnected from what's going on on the board, with stupid nonsensical horror checks. You make an app that doesn't keep tabs of where the characters are, their current conditions and what is surrounding them? Amateurish, to say the least.

If you decide to fully explore the mansion, you'll be bombarded by cultists and monsters which you need to spend you Investigator phase defeating, lest you're overwhelmed by their sheer numbers, all the while failing rolls for search or interact, which just drags the game on.

The worst part? The lore and clues you learn are meaningless. Imagine that. Stop the ritual by playing a game of mastermind after 3+ hours of trying to move through the mansion. Just terrible.

I've had my eye on this for a long time and a recent sale made this too cheap not to go for. I've never played the original and haven't liked most of the Arkham series (although I really like Arkham LCG). This game is kind of smack dab in the middle. It has a lot of elements of the LCG (like tight, focussed stories) but still has many core elements of the original Arkham (namely the dice chucking for tests).

Overall I was pretty impressed with the design. The app works surprisingly well as a random generator, and there seems to be a lot of content in it. For example, you'll walk into a room and several random features of the room will become highlighted as something you can search. The way that the app adds variation between plays is really interesting. The app is also used for some other mechanics as well such as delayed effects or triggered effects that are tightly integrated with your current map layout

The game itself is pretty streamlined. I like the new clue system (you can use clues to upgrade roles rather than reroll) and the conditions/possessions here felt most at home compared to other Arkham entries. The damage and horror effects here are some of the best of the line as well; rather than just accumulating chits you draw cards which may have other associated effects with them. Insanity doesn't mean the end of the game but it does trigger some very interesting changes that can be almost Betrayal at House on the Hill-ish. The game was also pretty easy to learn as you can mostly follow along with the app and then transition to the Learn to Play manual

The combat is simplistic but it works. It drags on after a bit and I found myself no longer reading the flavor text just to speed things along. In the end my first game (including setup and some brief rulebook digging) took 3.5 hours which was way too long. I could maybe get this down to 2 hours, but there is a lot of drudgery and upkeep which gets old

The core game is good and the app does a lot to immerse you. Rather than shuffling decks of cards you can click a button and the stories the app generates are much better than your standard Arkham formula of generic nonsense. The game is way too long for what it is though so it's hard for me to unwaveringly recommend

EDIT: The app integration is well-done in the sense that unexpected things will happen between plays. The combat is very, very random though and the scenarios play out similarly from game to game. It's also quite long and context switching between the game and the app gets old

For a big giant thematic game like this, it does it's job pretty well. I get people who don't want apps in their games, but this nicely helps. It gives you ambient and appropriate music, can give you varied clues and scenarios and map layouts, and it helps track such a fiddly game with less clutter and tokens and counters needed for the players.

In the end then you get a pretty great gothic horror experience of searching out a haunted place, gathering items and clues, and trying to beat down the monsters and figure out what's been going on.

It's not something I'll want to play too often, but a few times a year with the right group will give a pretty good time.

The main issue here is that the game doesn't quite know what it's trying to be though. It mostly tries to give you a feeling of exploration, as you are offered many choices to interact with objects and tokens and find new rooms, etc. However, the game doesn't give you enough time to interact and do everything in a scenario, so winning relies on doing the right things. Only it doesn't tell you for sure what those are. You have to sort of intuit it based on the flavor text and clues you've been getting. Which...like doesn't fully work, you have to intuit the same way the designers want you to, which isn't at all guaranteed, and now you can't just explore and check things out unless you want to repeatedly play a scenario, which is sort of what you have to do to learn how to win.

Which puts this close to my issues with Betrayal at House on the Hill, which also tries to be a good storytelling game but confuses itself and puts way too many rules and decisions on the players then that get in the way. If you want to be a strategic/tactical game with many meaningful choices, that's one thing, but you have to then inform players to allow them to make said choices. Otherwise if you want to allow exploration and story to take to the front, you've got to not put timer pressure or as many gameplay elements in the way. Trying to do both doesn't really work well here--you can't have a great strategic experience with so much obfuscated, but you can't have a great exploration experience with so much pressure from the game/strategy elements limiting what you have time to explore.

When you have dropped an item 5 times in a game through some "mysterious force", it is no longer funny. Also these tests feel totally random, because they force a random character to test a random attribute, which you cannot influence except by spending clue tokens, which are also given out randomly. All the items you get that are supposed to help you performing those tests are also mostly random drops, so you might only get items that are useless to you, and there is not enough time in the game to do a lot of trading between the players. 3 of the sides of the 8-sided dice for attribute tests are blank, so you are rolling a lot of frustrating misses.

In some scenarios, you have investigated for 4 hours, only to hit a hidden threshold were the game transforms from an exiting clue hunt into an unwinnable, boring combat situation, still including those stupid random attribute tests in the mythos phase each round. We quit several scenarios after this point, because we were too disappointed and bored to continue.

There is no undo button in the app, so if you accidentally click on something, you might break your progress from the last 2 to 4 hours. You can't change the difficulty of the game and the difficulty rating for each scenario is not accurate for all player counts, so you might pick an "easy" scenario and still get destroyed with only 2 investigators. It needs a "I want to experience the story" difficulty like the Arkham Horror LCG and / or some better scaling.

On that topic: This game does not work well as a 2-player game with each player controlling a single investigator. All scenarios get much more difficult and you are just running around much more, as the number of places you need to go is basically the same as in a game with 4 investigators. Aquí tienes las reglas básicas de *Mansions of Madness* en 15 puntos:

1. **Objetivo**: Los jugadores cooperan para investigar una serie de eventos misteriosos en una mansión. El objetivo es resolver el misterio y cumplir con los objetivos del escenario antes de que el tiempo o las amenazas acaben con ellos.

2. **Componentes**: El juego incluye un tablero modular, miniaturas, cartas, fichas, dados personalizados y un libro de escenarios.

3. **Preparación**: Elige un escenario (puede ser jugado de forma independiente o como parte de una campaña) y coloca las piezas del tablero según las instrucciones del escenario. Cada jugador selecciona un investigador con habilidades únicas.

4. **Investigadores**: Cada jugador controla un investigador, el cual tiene habilidades especiales y se inicia con un equipo específico, representado por cartas.

5. **Turnos**: Los jugadores se turnan en el siguiente orden: investigar, mover, atacar, interactuar con objetos o personajes, y resolver las acciones.

6. **Movimientos**: Los investigadores se mueven a través del tablero, explorando nuevas áreas, interactuando con objetos y buscando pistas.

7. **Acciones**: En su turno, un jugador puede realizar dos acciones, como moverse, buscar pistas, abrir puertas, atacar, usar objetos, o interactuar con personajes.

8. **Dados de acción**: Las acciones del juego se resuelven usando dados de habilidad. Los resultados de los dados se comparan con las habilidades del investigador para determinar el éxito o fracaso.

9. **Habilidades**: Cada investigador tiene diferentes atributos (como fuerza, agilidad, intelecto y voluntad) que afectan el resultado de las tiradas de dados.

10. **Monstruos**: El escenario incluye enemigos (monstruos o criaturas) que los jugadores deben enfrentar. Los monstruos actúan en su turno y pueden causar daño a los investigadores.

11. **Salud y cordura**: Los investigadores tienen puntos de salud y puntos de cordura. Cuando se quedan sin salud, se desmayan; cuando pierden toda la cordura, sufren efectos psicológicos negativos.

12. **Objetos y habilidades**: Los investigadores pueden encontrar objetos o habilidades especiales durante el juego, que les ayudarán a avanzar en su investigación o a defenderse de los monstruos.

13. **Fuego y oscuridad**: En Mansions of Madness, la oscuridad juega un papel importante en ciertos escenarios. Los jugadores pueden usar fuentes de luz, como linternas o velas, para iluminar áreas oscuras, lo que les permite explorar sin sufrir penalizaciones. La oscuridad reduce la visibilidad y puede aumentar el peligro, ya que algunos monstruos o eventos se ven potenciados en la oscuridad. El fuego, como una fuente de luz, puede también servir para atacar a los enemigos o iluminar caminos, pero su uso puede tener consecuencias, como la propagación de llamas que afecten a los investigadores o al entorno. El fuego en Mansions of Madness se extiende a todas las casillas adyacentes a la fuente de fuego. Esto incluye las casillas adyacentes en las direcciones horizontales, verticales y diagonales.
